pros: Nothing to necessarily write home about, but there is decent downtime on shift.
cons: No major cons either, it's really standard

review_title: The Best Employer I've Had Thus Far
pros: Very cooperative supervisors and coworkers in a friendly environment that helps provide a good gateway into other jobs within the facility (if you're looking for that kind of opportunity), while also being very flexible with university / class schedules.
cons: The only time I can think of where there is a "con" is when the day just turns out to be slow. Even then, it's nothing that you can realistically control since slow days just happen no matter where you are, and the day still doesn't get worse to any significant degree because of it.

review_title: Loved having a job on campus
job_title: Special Events Coordinator in Muncie, IN
pros: - Walking distance - Flexible schedule - Fun
cons: - Didn't pay well for the work that was being done

pros: The health benefits are great. If you commute into Muncie, traffic is light. The Campus is Beautiful and the pay was competitive. It was also enjoyable to wear many hats since the engineering crew is small.
cons: There are great people at Ball State University that are ignored and actively shut down by Good-ol'-boy management. The death of any institution comes when reputation building exceeds growth mindsets. Reputation builders are not looking to lift some boats in the harbor but rather work to be seen as the most important boat in the pond. Reputation builders prioritize how others perceive their looks so much they are willing to compromise the whole institution in their quest for perfection. All resources are leveraged to keep new ideas and growing pains of the crew from "rocking the boat." All means are used to keep the exterior paint from forming any blemish, blemishes created by dinging other boats in the harbor into the pier, or even the use of the boat itself (open dialogue, being disagreeable, or constructive criticism). Meanwhile, the timber and planks of the boat are rotting, the underside of the vessel below the water line is laboring under the weight of barnacles, and the condition of the thwart is bad enough it begins to scare off customers from entering the sinking boat. Downward it moves until the weight of the water collapses the pristinely painted walls under the slightest wave or impact with other vessels. Reputation builders see through the filter of 'zero-sum' value: if an idea or proposal isn't theirs, their value is diminished somehow. If subordinates exhibit needed growth or imperfection, this reflects poorly on them, and they must eliminate it. When good people are quiet in their duties. When money is diverted to work, that maximizes goodwill among department heads and leadership rather than repairing decaying infrastructure or constructive innovation. When the smell of spirits twists within the breath of pandering masters. When departments form into insular tribes, and blame is cast instead of enthusiasm to find a solution, reputation builders are commanding the ship. Be advised to find another ship. Find a vessel that bears the marks of good use and of a happy and diverse crew that greats happy guests. This institution leaves its customers with smiles and joyfully maintains and improves the ship from the rudder to the bow after departing on exciting and, at times, risky adventures.

review_title: Great Place to Work, but Not a Fan of Muncie
pros: I really like the leadership, and the university has a great culture. I've worked at other universities that were much more toxic. My particular department has a lot of flexibility and so I have achieved a good work-life balance. I am encouraged to continue learning professionally and have a lot of support in doing so.
cons: From the title, I am not a fan of Muncie! While not as dangerous as other cities in Indiana, I did not feel safe there. Strangely, there seems to be a lot of animosity from locals on the presence of a large university in "their town". Many faculty and staff live closer to Indianapolis.

pros: Tuition was almost free when working as a graduate assistant
cons: To advance your career, you should get a graduate assistantship similar to the field you want to be in

pros: work life balance is good, and pay decent
cons: pay could increase a bit

review_title: Toxic work environment, tenure likely on its way out.
pros: I suppose it is a job, though I made much more with much less work in the private sector.
cons: As a pre-tenure faculty member, each year I am here there is less and less incentive to stay. Any benefit tenure might have had is being replaced by a larger work load, with zero additional compensation. Steer clear of this place, I will be leaving as soon as I can find another position. HR is no help, chain of command is no help. RUN dont walk away.

review_title: Stagnant wages, and a University that fundamentally does not care about its employees
pros: If you live in Muncie, it may be your best (or only) option.
cons: Wages start low and will not budge unless you completely change departments. In my five years at BSU, I never received more than a 2% raise, and with inflation that's basically less than nothing. When I asked for a substantial raise due to a massive expansion of my job duties, I was told that upper management declared they "didn't need more managers, they need more doers", despite those upper managers being so out of touch with employees that they don't even remember names. The University's broad vision under President Mearns is aggressively expansionist, focused solely on bringing in more tuition dollars. They build multimillion dollar buildings while critical infrastructure fails in older buildings. The entire University is undersupported and understaffed, and they are doing absolutely nothing to retain employees.

review_title: Great work environment and space to learn
job_title: Student Desktop Support Technician in Muncie, IN
pros: The work environment is overall fun in Unified Technology Support (UTS), and it is one of the most "real" jobs a student can work on campus. Meaning students report to managers and are given real responsibilities in this role. This job is a great starting point for a career in IT or a related field.
cons: While students' direct managers are amazing and recognize the work the students do, upper management from time to time seem to take the students in this role for granted. This is shown by the students being paid minimum wage with no raise no matter what their responsibilities are or experience is. Other departments on campus pay their students more and will give them regular raises.

review_title: Mediocre institution, very out of touch, entrenched in the status quo
job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Muncie, IN
pros: Its a job, at a time when academics are less and less able to be choosy, I guess that's a good thing.
cons:
-Top heavy management structure--too much administration.
-Micromanagement of faculty
-Non-union
-Little autonomy
-No room for innovation
-Moving towards an adjunct/contract heavy faculty
-Incentive for tenure is virtually nil since new contract faculty are hired and retained at similar rates of pay.
-Openly hostile administrators, or those who pretend to listen but clearly are not invested in their faculty.
-Zero advocacy from unit heads to the dean level.

job_title: Supplemental Instructions (SI) Leader in Pendleton, IN
pros: Good work experience, good connections with professors and other students
cons: The position carries a lot of responsibility.

pros: They are trying. It seems that most people want the university to succeed and the admin is making hard decisions that will serve the university well in the distant future, even if it makes the present day a little rough.
cons: Most people are student focused but the majority, like much of higher ed, is trying to justify their job by over complicating things. This includes HR and Marketing. There are pockets of very dedicated people doing great work but the pay is low and the odds of working with others who are more worried about themselves or optics over students is high

pros:
While this is not the case for new employees, when I started here, the institution contributed 12.27% to 403(b)s. Great Anthem health insurance, Delta Dental, & VSP vision (optional). For Exempt, 24 vacation days, 12 sick days (that can accrue), and paid holidays. All of the above are intended to make-up for low pay; however, most faculty & staff are becoming intolerant of this messaging. If it's applicable to you, the tuition benefit it great too. 

One reason a lot of people stay here is for the tuition benefit, and other than the hospital, it's really the only significant employer in town. The other reason is the retirement benefits. With a minimum age and years of service, you can take your health insurance with you for life. However, over the years, they keep raising the minimum age requirement.

Faculty can control their time (except for courses) as they please; however, Professional and Support Staff are locked at their desks M-F 8am-5pm and more with events, etc.
cons:
The culture and work environment have steadily and significantly declined over the past 20 years. This used to be a positive, student-focused campus. Now virtually every "leader" (department chairs, deans, VPs, etc.) are all outside hires. There's no effort to develop or retain talent, which is already a huge challenge as most people want to live in Indianapolis (a 40-60min commute) as Muncie is a dying town.

Many "leaders" are clearly only concerned about building their own resumes and then moving onto somewhere else. The money for athletics and some leaders' focus on research run counter to what this institution, founded as a Teachers College, has always been known for. 

There's also big talk about Diversity & Inclusion, but in practice this only applies to race and sexual orientation. 

There is also zero option to ever work from home.

pros: Good benefits for families and retirement.
cons: Lack of vision at the institution.

pros: Working with the students is the most rewarding part of the job. Imparting my wisdom from years of experience - make me feel like I'm able to give back to a younger generation
cons: I'm not a fan of the academic politics and the tensions of in-fighting... I wouldn't last long as a tenure track professor- I'd probably upset to many people. Working part time as an adjunct is a way for me to engage with the student community but I often feel like my hands are tied and then the higher ups are surprised when things go sideways..

cons: Pay wasn’t great but the job was easy

pros: technology is state of the art
cons: Salaries are lower than comparable institutions.

pros: A fun work environment with good people
cons: As a student can only make minimum wage

pros: Variety of education and post graduation plan
cons: Commitment to excellence is on and off

review_title: Excellent place to work and to raise a family!
pros:
Good employee benefits
Cheap housing
Peaceful and quiet
cons: May not be ideal for singles

job_title: Creative Director, Ball State Journalism Workshops in Muncie, IN
pros: Positive work environment that fosters creativity and cooperation. Can't say enough good things.
cons: Minimum wage pay is a con

pros: Good work environment. Enjoyed time here.
cons: Location was challenging sometimes if you prefer city.

pros: Flexible schedule, reasonable hours, friendly coworkers and supervisor, allows you to put your education first
cons: Minimum wage, job application process was confusing

pros: good benefits and health care options, 401K
cons: hard to move up in hourly staff positions

pros:
Flexible Schedule
Easy workload
Time to do homework
cons:
Interview process makes you go to the career center which is not needed
Sometimes boring

pros: Really flexible with schedule, good hours for students, close walk.
cons: Not the best pay for struggling college students.

pros: Great people, great work environment
cons: None to report right now

pros: Positive and encouraging but also challenging
cons: Not a single one in my opinion

pros: Good Benefits any base pay
cons: Work Multiple jobs and not year roung

review_title: A good place to learn on the job, but no opportunities to progress rapidly.
pros:
Learning on the job. Requirements must be met but usually there is no dire need to get things done "today". This allows one to step back and take necessary time to really attack a project, finding an appropriate solution.

Flexible management. They are usually great to work with and cope well to the fact that they work in an educational environment and not a Fortune 500 company.
cons:
Mostly supportive staff, however, faculty can be a bit difficult to work with depending on department and expectations of professors. At times, expectations of job requirements are not parallel with existing staff ability, resources, or funds.

Benefits are horrible; insurance is sub-par for such an institution. Salary for professors is sub-par as well.

review_title: Excellent place to work, great administration!
pros: Ball State has come a long way in the past 10 years, and the new president (Dr. Paul Ferguson) and his administration is building on the university's strengths and taking it to the next level. Folks who are smart, adaptable and open to evolving are highly successful in this environment. Objectives and goals are so transparent they are, in fact, posted online for all to see, including progress measurements. That's what you call accountability. President Ferguson lives his philosophy of "servant leadership," which is defined by sharing power, putting the needs of others first, and helping people develop and perform at their best. Those who appreciate being held accountable for their contributions, and can put others' needs before their own, thrive in this culture. There are a lot of good people here, and most of them are smart enough to see that this is a very exciting time to be at Ball State!
cons: Transition is challenging for many people -- not really a negative -- if you look at it as opportunity, you will see doors flying open.

review_title: High tolerance for people with entitlement-mentality required.
pros: Good pay, steady work, opportunity for learning & development courses
cons: Faculty have major sense of entitlement, staff are treated like 2nd class citizens (or worse), HR hasn't updated job requirements since the 70s, failing to take into account the changes in the workplace, no chance to really advance

pros: There is good job security.
cons: Faculty are arrogant and treat staff with disdain.  I've never worked with so many sexist people in my life.  Pay increases are a joke - they don't even keep up with cost of living increases.  Parking is ridiculously overpriced.  Food on campus is also overpriced (and if you leave to dine elsewhere, good luck finding a place to park upon your return).  The administration is clueless about how things operate in academic departments and create more problems than they solve (for staff; faculty "solve" problems by handing the mess over to the staff).  There is no opportunity for advancement.

pros:
- It is a very high salary for the amount of responsibilities.
- It is easy to move up to full time from part time.
- Very easy to pick up an extra shift if you want the over time.
cons:
- They are not very good at communicating to their employees. 
- Not all buildings are open during the summer months or winter months when students aren't present, meaning that you don't have work for weeks at a time. 
- The parking is a nightmare. 
- It is difficult to get a position that works around your schedule. Most times, you settle for hours that don't actually work for you, just because the pay is good.

job_title: Chemistry Graduate Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: I was more than "real world ready" to substitute teach in the Indianapolis township schools like Westlane MS, Belzer MS, North Central HS, and Lawrence North HS.
cons: I graduated with a Master of Arts in Chemistry in Dec 2016. I had been hearing rumor and gossip that they just wanted me to stay longer. I wasn't allowed to change my mind in Jan 2017 and finish with a Master of Science in Chemistry.  Just goes to show you can't rely on gossip and rumors to be true.

review_title: Awesome job; Wish it paid more!
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: Upper management is very easy to work with. I currently work in the Ofc. Of the Dean, and all staff are extremely pleasant. The work is easy to do, and the direct manager even integrates special projects that are relative to the student's major. You are given more hours during breaks (winter, spring, and summer). That's right! The job is year-round which is pretty awesome.
cons: The work can be quite redundant. Pay is only minimum wage, which isn't bad only if you don't have much to pay for. If you're paying bills on a regular basis, you will need a second job.

review_title: The experience of being a graduate assistant varies depending on who you work for.
pros: Some projects that you work for are excellent resume builders. When selecting your G.A. position, make sure you're not just working a service job that is just paying for your tuition.
cons: Depending on your faculty member, you could be swamped with more than 20 hours of work. Your coworkers quickly realize that the department would be losing out on money if they were to get fired. With that in mind, GAs are prone to flaking out of work, which can detriment team based projects.

pros: easy academic atmosphere. 3 month long summer vacation.  job hours. seeing young man and woman grow and mature (most of time)
cons: lack of challenge to expand beyond the current job description.  As long as you get your tenure, all is well. Lack of cooperation among academics. Ivory tower mentality. The pay could be better. I don't understand where our revenue is generated, but I would guess the more we pull paying students in the higher profit we could make.  Why makes us less attractive compare to other schools nearby ?  What makes us better?  How should we differentiate from others?  Why am I not seeing these ?

job_title: GRADUATE ASSISTANT IN COMPUTER SCIENCE in Noblesville, IN
pros:
As a Graduate Assistant, there are a lot of pro's to being involved with Ball State, though these many times are specific to department.
-I have a great educational cost reduction package, I pay very little in Educational fees for the classes that I take.
-They also offer decent semester compensation, though no where near living wages, It is enough to really help out, and decrease the number of loans I require.
- My advisor, and the department as a whole tends to be very accommodating, and kind.
cons: I don't have a whole lot of cons. Maybe I'm the glass half full kind of person, but this is much better than previous positions.

pros: Free room and board, excellent staff, quality and dedicated hall directors.  This position as an RA truly developed me as an individual and enabled me to grow in a lot of ways -- especially leading students.  I would say that I have grown as a leader as I put on programs, attended diversity sessions, worked extensively as a team, and worked in conjunction with upper staff and staff between buildings.
cons: 2am curfew, numerous weekly meetings, had to attend a lot of outside events (and by a lot I mean a few...but they're all still extra!)

pros: Some decent benefits. Some nice people.
cons: High turnover...three supervisors in four years. Supervisor hired with no experience who doesn’t know staff jobs. Staff members opinions don’t matter. 16 years of employment don’t count if the new supervisor comes in and immediately wants new staff in the office. Low salaries with very small raises even with very good performance evaluations. Parking fees and health insurance premiums increase each year. Take home pay can be lower because of these expenses.

review_title: Great place to work, but difficult to be promoted
pros:
Great Campus
Great Environment
Nice people
Good retirement plan
Excellent time off provision
Ability to further education
cons:
Good ole boy network keeps qualified people from being promoted
VERY political - upset the wrong person, and you're doomed
Mostly "homegrown" employees create a closed culture
Creativity is hindered
Most employees do not have any non-academic experience

pros: There is a lot of support for student workers and the university is very flexible with scheduling. The faculty and staff are very willing to give letters of recommendation.
cons: Some of the tasks that are assigned to student workers are menial and they seem more like personal assistant task. It would be much better for the student to be challenged than be bored with the position.

review_title: Graduate Student Research Assistantship Review of Experience
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: My graduate assistantship was enough to cover my rent and other living expenses from month to month (but not much more).
cons: I didn't learn anything through my assistantship (i.e., faculty members in the program I was enrolled in treated graduate​ assistants as though we were paid to do any/all tasks rather than those which would provide opportunities to improve research or teaching skills).

review_title: Overall good workplace, but some frustrations
pros: Casual work environment, excellent job security, coworkers are excellent.
cons: Numerous OLD systems used for ERP systems and other processes.  These are a PAIN to support!  Some areas understaffed due to the current hiring freeze, leaving existing employees stretched too thin.  A few systems purchased recently have performed poorly after implementation on campus.  I wish these had been selected based on quality rather than cost.

pros: Great place, great people, excellent professors and colleagues who take great pride in their work
cons: Politics, the "Ball State Bounce" (getting bounced from one department to a other just to get a simple answer), the. Prong Muncie community

pros: While the duties of a graduate assistant vary greatly depending on your placement, Ball State does a good job of regulating hours to not overwork the students.  My bosses have been extremely helpful, and interested in my career development.
cons: The pay is rather low compared to GA's at other schools, but keep in mind the living expenses here are cheaper.  Sometimes the work can be trivial, but needs to be done by someone.

job_title: Clinic Staff Graduate Student in Muncie, IN
pros: A very supportive and friendly environment to be a part of. Hours are flexible, responsibilities are straightforward. A stress-free job.
cons: Sometimes, in case of client emergencies, closing staff was required to stay past the closing hours, but luckily this isn't something that is typical to happen. I cannot really think of any other cons.

job_title: MAC Tour Guide in Muncie, IN
pros: The work atmosphere is comfortable and fun. I especially like how involved you get with other departments, and casual the workplace is. The office really tries to work with your schedule and give you hours depending on that.
cons: As a student worker, it can be hard to find work to do around the office sometimes. A lot of the job requires to reorganize tasks and work because of the many instances of disorganization you will deal with.

review_title: Wish they were as creative in their vision for the entire university as they claim.
pros: Tries hard to be cutting edge in technology and has instituted creative collaborative capstone projects for students.
cons: Administration is short-sighted and often overlooks creative work being done by faculty that is not only aimed at creating a 'big buzz' but enhances fields in traditional ways as well.

review_title: Work hard for little recognition, disappointing compensation, and dismal benefits.
pros: Working on a beautiful college campus feels great. It's a living showplace. The facilities are gorgeous (when not under renovation).
cons: The institution claims it values innovation, and encourages employees to work hard to develop innovative solutions, but rarely recognizes the hard work, and hardly ever implements ideas which come from the bottom-up. Management believes creativity and innovation happen at the top and trickle down. It's the fast track to complacency for young professionals.

pros: Room & Board is paid for, experience with crisis management, event management, facility management. Interactions and relationships built with residents make it worth it.
cons: Sometimes there is a bad bunch of staff members you will have to interact with. Sometimes it's hard for those people to get fired, no matter how much wrong they do. If you work through it, you'll be fine.

job_title: Information Systems Department Technician in Muncie, IN
pros: Other student workers are always willing to help you out when needed.  You will make a lot of good connections that will lead to great references for a future job if you can at least perform to the average standard.
cons: The pay is the same as anywhere on campus for a student employee which is minimum wage.  Yet, the connections you make and what you learn far outweigh the pay especially if you do not have a lot of experience on a resume.

pros: If you are an out of state student going to graduate school, you will only pay in-state tuition as a grad assistant. Many departments on campus give opportunities to learn and grow as you attend school. I was able to develop my project management skills that have carried past my graduate assistantship. You also have the freedom to make mistakes.
cons: Occasionally not enough work to fill the 20 hour minimum. Depending on what department you're in, you may not get as much relevant experience

review_title: Every Ball State student looking for their first job on campus, you need to start here.
pros: Personal growth, friendly, fun, can some times be very upbeat, works around your schedule, and you get breaks when school is out.
cons: Sometimes they can ask you to do a lot, and working night staff can be a hard task.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Muncie, IN
pros: Ball State is one of the largest employers in the Muncie area. The university provides many types of positions both in and outside of academics.
cons: Pay scales often don't make sense across departments. Opportunities for growth really depend on the department and time  in addition to your skill set.

pros: If you like friendly, energetic and a mid size campus then this is the place for you. Housing gets paid for, exposed to a lot of customer service experience, and teaches you how do schedule through the most trying of times.
cons: Unless you are in a administrative position then it would be hard to make ends meet without getting a second job. But for college students that live in the dorms and need their housing paid for then this is it.

pros: being a graduate assistant allows you to get a great professional experience while you still go to school. Also, you are in most cases exempt from paying tuition.
cons: Sometimes, your boss can be too demanding and ask you to do more. Therefore you might not have enough time for the classes you are taking.

pros: You can expand on the skills you already have or pick up brand new ones. It also provides a great segue into your real-world career.
cons: Who your supervisor is controls almost the entire experience. Some will be great, while others will be terrible and treat you poorly.

pros: Ball State's management of student employment is excellent. Job searching beginning at the Career Center is easy and informative if you're not sure which direction to start in. Applying is even simpler and response rate from employers via application status is very prompt. All on-campus student employers are more than happy to adjust work days/hours based on student commitments.
cons: The pay is minimum wage, but it's great to have a steady income because it definitely adds up!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros:
I worked two positions and Ball State, one as an undergrad and one as a graduate assistant.

Supervisors are generally very aware that their student employees are students first, employees second.
Employers are usually willing to be flexible with a student employee's schedule (within reason).
Can provide an opportunity to work with people in your field depending on what your interest or focus is.
cons: There really isn't any opportunity for advancement (but that doesn't always matter to a student employee)

review_title: Ball State was a great experience and overall I've gained work experience, knowledge, and a sense of professionalism
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: Your work hours and flexibility. The office ladies for my department always incorporated your schedule and worked around that to ensure you got the maximum hours you could while attending college courses
cons: The pay is considerably low considering the amount of work you do however; because of this I've gained knowledge of a better budget and a strong work ethic.

pros: Flexible schedule, good pay for a college student, and great atmosphere
cons: There weren't any cons that I can think of other than parking in the winter time. Being a student and an employee was difficult because I had to park in student parking and it was far away from my job.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: Hours were flexible and were easy to schedule around classes. Could study/do homework during downtime. Fun atmosphere and coworkers. Gained good experience in general office work and reception- answering phones, scheduling appointments, etc. Great place to work on communication skills.
cons: Minimum wage pay. Admissions/scholarship season can get hectic.

review_title: Amazing Experience at the Digital Corps
pros: The Digital Corps office has an effective production process and a highly supportive staff. The work is fulfilling and during your time as a student there's plenty of room to develop highly needed professional skills in all areas of emerging media and project management.
cons: University board keeps diverting money away from various departments of the school to dump more money into athletics so work sometimes entails doing more with less.

pros: Although salaries aren't as high as in the private sector, the educational, retirement, and PTO benefits are superb.  Graduate assistants receive free tuition.
cons: The current economic situation has stagnated salaries for the past two years.  It would be nice if BSU offered pay for performance programs.

pros: Convenient location, flexible schedule. Hourly pay when on school breaks and able to work as many hours as desired on vacation times like Christmas break, summer, etc.
cons: No opportunities for advancement, pay rate determined by graduate school. Sometimes don't always get the job you want but have to settle for what is available.

pros:
- good benefits
- good pay
- flexible time
- short commute
- small classes

Good place for teaching. Has strong focus on classroom quality. New president (Gora) has shaken up and improved a number of things.
cons:
- location
- everyone strives to be mediocre
- bureaucracy

Students are mostly local and unmotivated. Coworkers want to be left alone. Administration does not communicate much.

review_title: You can make it what ever you want.
pros: I had lots of freedom with curriculum, and a fair amount of support from colleagues.
cons: Pay at Ball State is at the bottom of the national range. Muncie is not a destination for much. The industry is in decline. Finding a job for a spouse will be difficult unless you are willing to commute to Indianapolis.

job_title: Lead Computer Systems Technician in Muncie, IN
pros: Very immersive environment, a lot of great experience with multiple departments and differing technologies
cons: Pay is much less than other Universities, sometimes you are left on your own which can be both a good and bad thing depending on the situation

pros:
Real world experience
Networking
Personal relationships
Flexibility
Understanding that school comes first
On campus
Some type of free food or candy every week
cons:
Minimum wage
Can only work 20 hours
"Grunt" work
No raises
Inefficient management
"Old school" data management techniques
Seniority rules

review_title: Great for Students - Conferences and Special Events Assistant
job_title: Conferences and Special Events Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: Flexible hours to accommodate with classes, real-world experience in the office setting, awesome bosses who threw appreciation parties for the student workers, located on campus
cons: I've always felt as if student workers should be allowed to work more than 20 hours a week; but, other than that, no cons. No benefits, as this is a student's job.

review_title: At Ball State we stay the same and just shuffle our feet a bit
pros: Excellent benefits, very clean campus
cons: Not receptive to change, very political

pros:
Worked with your class schedule
Genuine people
Gave you time to get homework done
cons:
Some professors take advantage and have you do a lot of their work
Some of the office work is not well thought out

pros: Technology advances prevent work from being mundane Benefits of low cost tuition after 2 years of service. Public employee retirement fund also a big plus. Most people retire from here!
cons: Vehicles are becoming more technologically advanced, more tools and diagnostic equipment needed to keep pace with demands. Lack of equipment in reserve to put in place of break down.

pros:
- Coworkers are excellent. The people I worked WITH were great friends.
- Opportunities to learn and grow within a position.
cons: - Management has created a terrible culture in which employees are afraid to express concerns out of fear of repercussions.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: Its nice to work on campus and not worry about transportation to work. Its also nice to be able to get paid the same time as all your other friends who work on campus.
cons: They start you at minimum wage no matter what. My job is highly skilled, and I'd make 14/hour elsewhere. I've been considering quitting for a while now.

pros: Ball State exists on a beautiful campus and the University has a large number of dynamic professors and assistant professors who go well beyond expectations to meet the needs of students.
cons: Assistant professor salaries are low.  Contract professors are not permitted to accept additional responsibilities for additional pay.

review_title: Amazing place with AWESOME people and opportunities
job_title: Public Relations Intern in Muncie, IN
pros: I had multiple leadership positions in organizations and a part-time job at the Digital Corps. Amazing place to work. You are put into situations that test you and your limits, in the best way possible.
cons: It's sometimes hard to focus when there is so much awesome happening around you.

pros:
If you get along with college students, it can be a lot of fun.
You meet some great people
You can take classes as an employee
cons:
Work is very limited in the summer
Management doesn't really listen to you much

review_title: This job was an excellent way to make money while being a full time student.
job_title: Housing Desk Staff in Scottsdale, AZ
pros:
-Fits into class schedule
-can do homework while working
-flexible hours
cons: -Relying on other students to fill open positions or switch shifts

pros: Some faculty are very interested in seeing you succeed
cons:
Your contract stipulates that you will only work 20 hours per week however it will definitely be more than that. 

It was hard to find more than 1 faculty member that did not actively try to take advantage of you as a graduate student.

review_title: Held various student jobs; satisfied with all
pros: Bosses were very understanding of student status and willing to work with you for scheduling and work-load purposes.
cons: Compensation is minimum wage; hours per week are limited to 20 between all jobs. This is law and not going to change, so you have to trade compensation for a sane work-life balance.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: Good experience, lots of autonomy, opportunities for professional development
cons: Little to no control over courses taught, poor community development, no benefits

pros: I worked as a student worker in both dining and transportation and enjoyed both jobs. The people were nice and the experience was overall a positive one.
cons: As a student worker I was paid minimum wage in dining and slightly higher in transportation. You can only work up to 20 hours a week as we'll.

review_title: Not bad for what it is
job_title: Food Service Worker in Muncie, IN
pros: Pretty decent wage and often chances for extra hours. As a part time employee you can apply for full time position and get a pay raise and health benefits.
cons: Some buildings are very understaffed and work especially on weekends or for dinner can be overwhelming and stressful.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: There is competitive pay and good benefits.  The people are mostly friendly as well.  There is a small university feel with big university opportunities.
cons: Sometimes during the Winter it can get pretty old with the weather.  It feels like it will never end. Occasionally the daily grind can get tiresome.

review_title: Horrible management mixed with great management
pros: Top 3 Best Places to work in Muncie
cons: Academia is may not survive COVID-19

review_title: Working as a Graduate Assitant has its perks.
pros: over 70% of tuition is paid for, and you get a decent living stipend.
cons: SO MUCH WORK. but that's normal, and it's good work that'll help you in the future, so not really a con. It can just be hard to manage your time every now and then.

review_title: A fun work environment with friends.
job_title: Student Technology Assistant in Muncie, IN
pros: It's very relaxed and they are extremely flexible with scheduling.
cons: Most jobs on campus are capped at 20 hours per week and only pay minimum wage.

pros: Friendly environment. If you enjoy learning, tuition waived for employees to take courses on campus or online.
cons: No intentional plan for talent/career development.

pros:
Reliable and consistent work environment 
Flexible for students 
Helpful staff
Great opportunity for local residents to get involved in the university
cons: Transparency is an issue here, particularly the past few years with hiring the president of the university and explaining the dismissal of the previous one.

job_title: HelpDesk Desktop Support Consultant in Muncie, IN
pros: Flexible hours, great industry knowledge, great work environment.
cons: Minimum wage pay and only 20 hours a week.

job_title: Department Technology Specialist in Muncie, IN
pros: The hours were very flexible and you get to interact with professors outside the classroom environment. Can work on school work during down time.
cons: Challenges include low pay (minimum wage and there are no raises) and work can be trivial. I my specific department, management could be a lot better.

pros: The people to work with are fun, and the professor I worked for was wonderful. She always stressed to put my education before everything else, even my job.
cons: There can be those times where scheduling can inevitably conflict with class, if you're taking classes while working

pros: Ball State offers a wide variety of benefits involving interaction with students and diversity.
cons: Location - Muncie isn't the greatest, but the proximity to Indianapolis gives lots of opportunities for entertainment

pros: Professors will let you work around your class schedule.
cons: Professors can be demanding.  Working with undergraduate students can be rough.  They tend to throw tantrums and blame bad grades on the GA instead of their own lack of studying and effort.

pros: I am in math department and I work for three professors. Work environment is good. payment is good. I think It is not stressful so far.
cons: For some weeks, you do not have too much work to do, so you need to learn how to manage your time.

job_title: Residence Hall Desk Staff in Muncie, IN
pros: Hours as a student worker were great. Easy to work around classes and activities. I would highly recommend working here as a student.
cons: I really don’t have any cons about my position as a student. It was one of the better campus jobs a student could have.

review_title: Ball State School of Music was fantastic work at
job_title: Graphic Design Intern in Muncie, IN
pros:
Great sense of community. Everyone is friendly and easy to talk to.
I worked as a designer for them and was allowed a lot of artistic freedom.
cons: Only small problem was the lack of hours.

pros: There are many knowledgable people within the organization that are willing to help you with anything that you need.
cons: Just like many of the schools out there, it is becoming increasingly bureaucratic and difficult to accomplish anything without cutting through miles of red tape.

pros: Really relaxed environment very flexible hours and the highest paying student job on campus, plenty of time to do all the work required
cons: Pay still not that much, can not work weekends unless supervised , students can not work more than 20 hours per week

pros: Great benefits, hard to find in any other industry. Good place to raise a family, community cares about one and other.
cons: The community and school must come together for the positive growth of both. Both need to realize that they need each other.

pros: Nice coworkers/supervisors, allows you to get tutoring certification each semester. Increased pay each semester. Great experience
cons: Some disorganization between desk staff and tutors. Sometimes didn’t know what I was required to do as part of my training. hard to change schedule once it’s set. Low pay

pros:
You receive a discount on college classes
You get get total access to free gym/facilities membership
Their are good benefits regarding insurance and educatio
cons:
The job wasn't extremely challenging.
There was no room for advancement.
It is a very slow atmosphere and days drag by

review_title: RAing -Good gig to get you through some school bills
pros: You got what you put into it and most of the professional staff are amazing
cons: The hours and restrictions on your personal time

job_title: Substitute Bus Driver in Muncie, IN
pros: This job is very flexible with your schedule and you can more or less pick your own hours to an extent. Usually lots of overtime available.
cons: No benefits and you do as much work as the full time people but get paid less.

pros: Growing college, clean campus, good faculty.  You get a lot of free time as a graduate assistant, which allows you to concentrate on your studies while you're "on the clock".
cons: not a lot to do in the town.

pros:
The university was very flexible with my schedule and accommodating my diverse schedule every year
The management had a lot of trust in its employees
cons:
no opportunity for growth
no benefits (for my position)

review_title: Great Learning experience as a Graduate Assistant
pros: Real-time work experience being a Web Developer, practicing Professionalism, hands-on new projects, learning new technologies while doing part-time job, preparing for the future.
cons: Challenges includes Low Payment, Academic as well as job responsibilities and maintaining work/academic/life balance.

pros:
- Choose your own shifts (up to 20 hours)
- Negotiable management when complications arrive
- Great staff
cons: - The company only provides minimum wage

review_title: Good student job, especially if you need to study.
pros: Great for studying, bosses very flexible, regular set hours
cons: can be a little boring/not challenging. Very set in the way but thats necessary to manage students.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
pros: flexible hours, understand needs of a student, can be very accomodating, Great place to make some money
cons: can be very boring, and you may end up with a boss that is less than friendly or kind. I had one positive and one very bad experience with a supervisor the college later let go

pros:
+flexible hours for student schedules
+relatively easy to find a position related to your field of study
+in general, great people to work with
cons:
+student-positions often have low hours
+20 hour/ week max for student employees

review_title: Been good to me so far.
pros: autonomy—at least in my department; cordial colleagues; professional opportunities; affordable cost of living in Muncie; not far from major cities
cons: perceived town-and-gown divide; difficult to sell a house; roads need repair; lack of bicycle lanes or other pedestrian-friendly services

pros: Everyone is treated as an Individual
cons: Salary is not uniform even though some people do more than others they get paid lower

review_title: Invaluable and very much missed but quite different from the rest of the world.
pros: Very laid back and stress free for the most part.
cons: Like most state universities there is quite a bit of red tape to get through.

job_title: Peer Advocate Leader in Muncie, IN
pros:
-flexible
-a lot of interaction with students
-learning how to professional challenge peers and superiors
